sen.j: 高台寺（こうだいじ）は京都府京都市東山区にある臨済宗建仁寺派の寺院。
sen.e: Kodai-ji Temple is a Buddhist temple belonging to the Kennin-ji Temple school of the Rinzai sect located in Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.
Kodai-ji Temple is a Buddhist temple belonging to the Kennin-ji Temple school of the Rinzai sect located in Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.
Kodai-ji Temple is a Buddhist temple belonging to the Kennin-ji Temple school of the Rinzai Sect located in Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.
sen.cmt: sectの頭文字を大文字に修正

sen.j: 山号は鷲峰山（じゅぶさん）、寺号は詳しくは高台寿聖禅寺と称する。
sen.e: Its honorific mountain prefix is 'Jubusan' and the temple is formally identified as 'Kodai Jushozen-ji'.
Its honorific mountain prefix is 'Jubusan' and the temple is formally identified as 'Kodai Jushozen-ji'.
Its honorific mountain prefix is 'Mt. Jubu' and the temple is formally identified as 'Kodai Jushozen-ji'.
sen.cmt: 鷲峰山→Mt. Jubuとしました。

sen.j: 豊臣秀吉の正室である北政所（高台院）が秀吉の冥福を祈るため建立した寺院であり、寺号は北政所の落飾（仏門に入る）後の院号である高台院にちなむ。
sen.e: The temple was established by Kita no Mandokoro (Kodai-in), the lawful wife of Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, to pray for the soul of her late husband, and it was named 'Kodai-ji' after the name taken by Kita no Mandokoro when she became a Buddhist nun.

The temple was established by Kita no Mandokoro (Kodai-in), the lawful wife of Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, to pray for the soul of her late husband, and it was named 'Kodai-ji' after the name taken by Kita no Mandokoro when she became a Buddhist nun.

The temple was established by Kita no Mandokoro (Kodaiin), the lawful wife of Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, to pray for the soul of her late husband, and it was named 'Kodai-ji' after the name taken by Kita no Mandokoro when she became a Buddhist nun.
sen.cmt: 統一事項に基づき、Kodai-in→Kodaiinに修正

sen.j: 釈迦如来を本尊とする禅宗寺院であるとともに、秀吉と北政所を祀る霊廟としての性格をもった寺院である。
sen.e: Kodai-ji is a Zen temple with a principal image statue of Shaka Nyorai, but also has the characteristics of a mausoleum enshrining Hideyoshi and Kita no Mandokoro.
Kodai-ji is a Zen temple with a principal image statue of Shaka Nyorai, but also has the characteristics of a mausoleum enshrining Hideyoshi and Kita no Mandokoro.
Kodai-ji is a Zen temple with a principal image statue of Shaka Nyorai, but also has the characteristics of a mausoleum enshrining Hideyoshi and Kita no Mandokoro.

sen.j: 霊屋（おたまや）の堂内装飾には桃山様式の蒔絵が用いられ、北政所所持と伝えられる蒔絵調度類を多数蔵することから「蒔絵の寺」の通称がある。
sen.e: The interior of the mausoleum is decorated with Momoyama style (luxurious, splended and decorative style created during Momoyama Period) makie (Japanese lacquer sprinkled with gold or silver powder), and the temple has become nicknamed 'Makie Temple' for its many makie furnishings that are said to have once been owned by Kita no Mandokoro.

The interior of the mausoleum is decorated with Momoyama style (luxurious, splended and decorative style created during Momoyama Period) makie (Japanese lacquer sprinkled with gold or silver powder), and the temple has become nicknamed 'Makie Temple' for its many makie furnishings that are said to have once been owned by Kita no Mandokoro.

The interior of the mausoleum is decorated with Momoyama style (luxurious, splended and decorative style created during Momoyama Period) makie (Japanese lacquer sprinkled with gold or silver powder), and the temple has become nicknamed 'Makie Temple' for its many makie furnishings that are said to have once been owned by Kita no Mandokoro.
sen.cmt: 余分なスペースを削除

sen.j: 豊臣秀吉が病死したのは 慶長3年（1598年）であった。
sen.e: Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI passed away in 1598.
Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI passed away in 1598.
Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI passed away in 1598.

sen.j: 秀吉の正室である北政所（ねね、出家後は高台院湖月尼）は秀吉の菩提を弔うための寺院の建立を発願し、当初は北政所の実母・朝日局が眠る康徳寺（京都の寺町にあった）をそれに充てようとしたが、手狭であったため、東山の現在地に新たな寺院を建立することになった。
sen.e: His wife, Kita no Mandokoro, (who was also known as Nene and later took the name 'Kodai-in Kogetsuni' after becoming a Buddhist nun) vowed to establish a temple to pray to Buddha for the happiness of her late husband, and originally attempted to use Kotoku-ji Temple (used to be in Teramachi, Kyoto), in which her mother Asahi no Tsubone was buried, for this purpose but it was too small so she established a new temple on Kodai-ji Temple's current site in Higashiyama.

His wife, Kita no Mandokoro, (who was also known as Nene and later took the name 'Kodai-in Kogetsuni' after becoming a Buddhist nun) vowed to establish a temple to pray to Buddha for the happiness of her late husband, and originally attempted to use Kotoku-ji Temple (used to be in Teramachi, Kyoto), in which her mother Asahi no Tsubone was buried, for this purpose but it was too small so she established a new temple on Kodai-ji Temple's current site in Higashiyama.

His wife, Kita no Mandokoro, (who was also known as Nene and later took the name 'Kodaiin Kogetsuni' after becoming a Buddhist nun) vowed to establish a temple to pray to Buddha for the happiness of her late husband, and originally attempted to use Kotoku-ji Temple (used to be in Teramachi, Kyoto), in which her mother Asahi no Tsubone was buried, for this purpose but it was too small so she established a new temple on Kodai-ji Temple's current site in Higashiyama.

sen.j: 秀吉没後の権力者となった徳川家康は、北政所を手厚く扱い、配下の武士たちを高台寺の普請担当に任命した。
sen.e: After the Hideyoshi's death, Ieyasu TOKUGAWA took power but treated Kita no Mandokoro well and charged the samurai under his command with constructing Kodai-ji Temple.
After Hideyoshi's death, Ieyasu TOKUGAWA took power but treated Kita no Mandokoro well and charged the samurai under his command with constructing Kodai-ji Temple.
After Hideyoshi's death, Ieyasu TOKUGAWA took power but treated Kita no Mandokoro well and charged the samurai under his command with constructing Kodai-ji Temple.
sen.cmt: Hideyoshi’sのアポストロフィーを半角に修正

sen.j: 中でも普請掛・堀直政の働きは大きかったようで、高台寺の開山堂には直政の木像が祀られている。
sen.e: One of these builders, Naomasa HORI who was in charge of construction, put in such great effort that a wooden statue of him is enshrined in the Kaizan-do hall.
One of these builders, Naomasa HORI who was in charge of construction, put in such great effort that a wooden statue of him is enshrined in the Kaizan-do hall.
One of these builders, Naomasa HORI who was in charge of construction, put in such great effort that a wooden statue of him is enshrined in the Kaisan-do hall (Founder's hall).
sen.cmt: Kaizan-do hall→Kaisan-do hallに修正、補足を追加 (参照:http://www.kodaiji.com/guide/annai.html#)

sen.j: 創建当時の高台寺の仏殿は前述の康徳寺の堂を移築・改造したものであり、方丈、茶室などは伏見城から移築したものであった。
sen.e: The Buddha statue hall at Kodai-ji Temple at the time of its founding had been remodeled and relocated from the previously mentioned Kotoku-ji Temple, and other structures including the hojo (Abbot's quarters) and teahouse were relocated from Fushimi-jo Castle.

The Buddha statue hall at Kodai-ji Temple at the time of its founding had been remodeled and relocated from the previously mentioned Kotoku-ji Temple, and other structures including the hojo (Abbot's quarters) and teahouse were relocated from Fushimi-jo Castle.

The Buddha statue hall at Kodai-ji Temple at the time of its founding had been remodeled and relocated from the previously mentioned Kotoku-ji Temple, and other structures including the hojo (Abbot's quarters) and teahouse were relocated from Fushimi-jo Castle.

sen.j: また、伏見城の化粧御殿が移築されて、北政所の居所とされた。
sen.e: The Kesho Goten Palace (the dressing palace) of Fushimi-jo Castle was also moved to the temple where it served as the residence of Kita no Mandokoro.
The Kesho Goten Palace (the dressing palace) of Fushimi-jo Castle was also moved to the temple where it served as the residence of Kita no Mandokoro.
The Kesho Goten Palace (the dressing palace) of Fushimi-jo Castle was also moved to the temple where it served as the residence of Kita no Mandokoro.

sen.j: 高台寺の西側にある塔頭（たっちゅう、付属寺院）の圓徳院がその跡で、北政所は慶長10年（1605年）から寛永元年（1624年）に没するまでここに住んだ。
sen.e: To the west of Koda-ji Temple stand the remains of the Entoku-in, a minor affiliated temple, where Kita no Mandokoro resided from 1605 until her death 1624.
To the west of Koda-ji Temple stand the remains of the Entoku-in, a minor affiliated temple, where Kita no Mandokoro resided from 1605 until her death 1624.
A minor affiliated temple Entoku-in stands to the west of Koda-ji Temple as the remains of the Kesho Goten Palace, where Kita no Mandokoro resided from 1605 until her death 1624.
sen.cmt: 一部原文の内容に沿わない解釈となっており、「化粧御殿」の跡→「圓徳院」となるよう、文章を修正しました。

sen.j: 高台寺の開山は慶長11年（1606年）で、当初は曹洞宗の寺院であった。
sen.e: Kodai-ji Temple was founded in 1606 and was originally devoted to the Soto Sect.
Kodai-ji Temple was founded in 1606 and was originally devoted to the Soto Sect.
Kodai-ji Temple was founded in 1606 and was originally devoted to the Soto Sect.

sen.j: 寛永元年7月（1624年）、高台寺は臨済宗寺院である建仁寺の三江紹益を中興開山に招聘。
sen.e: In 1624, Kodai-ji Temple invited Rinzai Sect Kennin-ji Temple priest Sanko Joeki to serve as a reviving founder.
In 1624, Kodai-ji Temple invited Rinzai Sect Kennin-ji Temple priest Sanko Joeki to serve as a reviving founder.
In 1624, Kodai-ji Temple invited Rinzai Sect Kennin-ji Temple priest Sanko Joeki to serve as a reviving founder.

sen.j: この時、高台寺は曹洞宗から臨済宗に改宗している。
sen.e: It was at this time that Kodai-ji Temple converted from the Soto Sect to the Rinzai Sect.
It was at this time that Kodai-ji Temple converted from the Soto Sect to the Rinzai Sect.
It was at this time that Kodai-ji Temple converted from the Soto Sect to the Rinzai Sect.

sen.j: 北政所の兄・木下家定は建仁寺及び三江紹益と関係が深く、家定の七男が三江紹益のもとで出家していることも、この改宗と関連すると言われる。
sen.e: It is said that this conversion took place as a result of the close relationship that Kita no Mandokoro's elder brother, Iesada KINOSHITA, had to both Kennin-ji Temple and Sanko Joeki, and Sanko Joeki leading Iesada's 7th son to enter the priesthood.

It is said that this conversion took place as a result of the close relationship that Kita no Mandokoro's elder brother, Iesada KINOSHITA, had to both Kennin-ji Temple and Sanko Joeki, and Sanko Joeki leading Iesada's 7th son to enter the priesthood.

It is said that this conversion took place as a result of the close relationship that Kita no Mandokoro's elder brother, Iesada KINOSHITA, had to both Kennin-ji Temple and Sanko Joeki, and Sanko Joeki leading Iesada's 7th son to enter the priesthood.

sen.j: なお、北政所は同じ寛永元年の9月に没している。
sen.e: Kita no Mandokoro passed away the same September.
Kita no Mandokoro passed away the same September.
Kita no Mandokoro passed away the same September.

sen.j: 高台寺は、江戸時代後期の一時期、御陵衛士（高台寺党）の屯所となったこともある。
sen.e: In the latter part of the Edo period, Kodai-ji Temple temporarily served as the base of the Goryo Eji (a splinter group of the Shinsengumi).
In the latter part of the Edo period, Kodai-ji Temple temporarily served as the base of the Goryo Eji (a splinter group of the Shinsengumi).
In the latter part of the Edo period, Kodai-ji Temple temporarily served as the base of the Goryo Eji (Kodaiji-to Party, a splinter group of the Shinsengumi).
sen.cmt: 高台寺党を訳出しました。

sen.j: その後、近世末期から近代に至る数度の火災で仏殿、方丈などを焼失。
sen.e: Following this, the temple experienced numerous fires from the end of the modern era to the present day, which resulted in the destruction of the Buddha statue hall and the hojo.
Following this, the temple experienced numerous fires from the end of the modern era to the present day, which resulted in the destruction of the Buddha statue hall and the hojo.
Following this, the temple experienced numerous fires from the end of the modern era to the present day, which resulted in the destruction of the Buddha statue hall and the hojo.

sen.j: 創建時の建造物で現存しているのは、三江紹益を祀る開山堂、秀吉と北政所を祀る霊屋（おたまや）、茶室の傘亭と時雨亭などである。
sen.e: Structures remaining from the time of the temple's founding include the Kaizan-do hall enshrining a statue of Sanko Joeki, the mausoleum in which Hideyoshi and Kita no Mandokoro rest, and the teahouses named 'Kasa-tei' and 'Shigure-tei'.

Structures remaining from the time of the temple's founding include the Kaizan-do hall enshrining a statue of Sanko Joeki, the mausoleum in which Hideyoshi and Kita no Mandokoro rest, and the teahouses named 'Kasa-tei' and 'Shigure-tei'.

Structures remaining from the time of the temple's founding include the Kaisan-do hall enshrining a statue of Sanko Joeki, the mausoleum in which Hideyoshi and Kita no Mandokoro rest, and the teahouses named 'Kasa-tei' and 'Shigure-tei'.

sen.j: 創建当時存在した仏殿は焼失後再建されておらず、方丈が中心的な堂宇となっている。
sen.e: The original Buddha statue hall was not rebuilt after being destroyed by fire and the hojo became the center of the temple.
The original Buddha statue hall was not rebuilt after being destroyed by fire and the hojo became the center of the temple.
The original Buddha statue hall was not rebuilt after being destroyed by fire and the hojo became the center of the temple.

sen.j: 方丈の西に庫裏、北に書院があるが、いずれも創建当時のものではない。
sen.e: Neither the kuri (administration and food preparation building) to the west of the hojo nor the study to its north date from the time of the temple's founding.
Neither the kuri (administration and food preparation building) to the west of the hojo nor the study to its north date from the time of the temple's founding.
Neither the kuri (administration and food preparation building) to the west of the hojo nor the study to its north date from the time of the temple's founding.

sen.j: 境内東側には偃月池・臥龍池という2つの池をもつ庭園が広がり、開山堂、霊屋、茶室などが建つ。
sen.e: In the east of the temple precinct is a garden containing the Engetsu-ike Pond and Garyu-ike Pond, and in which the Kaizan-do, mausoleum and teahouses stand.
In the east of the temple precinct is a garden containing the Engetsu-ike Pond and Garyu-ike Pond, and in which the Kaizan-do, mausoleum and teahouses stand.
In the east of the temple precincts is a garden containing the Engetsu-ike Pond and Garyu-ike Pond, and in which the Kaisan-do hall, mausoleum and teahouses stand.

sen.j: また、境内からやや離れて黒門が建つ。
sen.e: The Kuromon gate stands slightly distant from the temple precinct.
The Kuromon gate stands slightly distant from the temple precinct.
The Kuro-mon gate stands slightly distant from the temple precincts.

sen.j: 庫裏－拝観順路入口に位置する。
sen.e: Kuri: Located at the entrance to the visitor's route.
Kuri: Located at the entrance to the visitor's route.
Kuri: Located at the entrance to the visitor's route.

sen.j: 内部は通常非公開。
sen.e: The interior is not ordinarily open to the public.
The interior is not ordinarily open to the public.
The interior is not ordinarily open to the public.

sen.j: 玄関から垣間見える「夢」と書かれた衝立が印象的である。
sen.e: A particularly impressive screen on which the character for 'Dream' is written can be seen from the entrance hall.
A particularly impressive screen on which the character for 'Dream' is written can be seen from the entrance hall.
A particularly impressive screen on which the character for 'Dream' is written can be seen from the entrance hall.

sen.j: 方丈－庫裏の右手に建つ。
sen.e: Hojo (Abbot's quarters): Stands to the right of the kuri.
Hojo (Abbot's quarters): Stands to the right of the kuri.
Hojo: Stands to the right of the kuri.
sen.cmt: 方丈の補足は前出のため省きました。

sen.j: 大正元年（1912年）の再建。
sen.e: Reconstructed in 1912.
Reconstructed in 1912.
Reconstructed in 1912.

sen.j: 創建当初の方丈は文禄の役後に伏見城の建物を移築したものであった。
sen.e: The original hojo was relocated to the temple from Fushimi Castle after the Japanese invasions of Korea.
The original hojo was relocated to the temple from Fushimi Castle after the Japanese invasions of Korea.
The original hojo was relocated to the temple from Fushimi-jo Castle after the Japanese invasions of Korea.

sen.j: 勅使門－方丈の南正面に位置する。
sen.e: Chokushi-mon gate (an imperial messenger gate): Stands at the south face of the hojo.
Chokushi-mon gate (an imperial messenger gate): Stands at the south face of the hojo.
Chokushi-mon gate (an imperial messenger gate): Stands at the south face of the hojo.

sen.j: 大正元年（1912年）に方丈とともに再建された。
sen.e: Reconstructed in 1912 along with the hojo.
Reconstructed in 1912 along with the hojo.
Reconstructed in 1912 along with the hojo.

sen.j: 書院－方丈の背後に建つ。
sen.e: Study: Stands behind the hojo.
Study: Stands behind the hojo.
Study: Stands behind the hojo.

sen.j: 観月台（重要文化財）－書院と開山堂を結ぶ屋根つき廊の途中にある小規模な建築である。
sen.e: Moon-viewing Pavilion (Important Cultural Property): A small building in the middle of the roofed corridor linking the study and the Kaizan-do hall.
Moon-viewing Pavilion (Important Cultural Property): A small building in the middle of the roofed corridor linking the study and the Kaizan-do hall.
Moon-viewing Pavilion (Important Cultural Property): A small building in the middle of the roofed corridor linking the study and the Kaisan-do hall.

sen.j: ここから北政所は亡き秀吉をしのびながら月を眺めたという。
sen.e: It is said that Kita no Mandokoro would sit here and gaze at the moon as she remembered the departed Hideyoshi.
It is said that Kita no Mandokoro would sit here and gaze at the moon as she remembered the departed Hideyoshi.
It is said that Kita no Mandokoro would sit here and gaze at the moon as she remembered the departed Hideyoshi.

sen.j: 開山堂（重要文化財）－書院の東方、庭園内に建つ入母屋造本瓦葺きの禅宗様の仏堂。
sen.e: Kaizan-do Hall (Important Cultural Property): A Zen style Buddhist statue hall with the Irimoya-styled roof (hip-and-gable roof) that stands to the east of the study.
Kaizan-do Hall (Important Cultural Property): A Zen style Buddhist statue hall with the Irimoya-styled roof (hip-and-gable roof) that stands to the east of the study.
Kaisan-do Hall (Important Cultural Property): A Zen style Buddhist statue hall with the Irimoya-styled roof (hip-and-gable roof) that stands to the east of the study.
sen.cmt: 余分なスペースを削除、Kaisan-do Hallとしました。

sen.j: 慶長10年（1605年）の建築。
sen.e: Constructed in 1605.
Constructed in 1605.
Constructed in 1605.

sen.j: 元来、北政所の持仏堂だったもので、その後、中興開山の三江紹益の木像を祀る堂となっている。
sen.e: The building was originally the private Buddhist statue hall of Kita no Mandokoro before being used to enshrine a wooden statue of reviving founder Sanko Joeki.
The building was originally the private Buddhist statue hall of Kita no Mandokoro before being used to enshrine a wooden statue of reviving founder Sanko Joeki.
The building was originally the private Buddhist statue hall of Kita no Mandokoro before being used to enshrine a wooden statue of reviving founder Sanko Joeki.

sen.j: 堂内は中央奥に三江紹益像、向かって右に北政所の兄の木下家定とその妻・雲照院の像、左に高台寺の普請に尽力した堀直政の木像を安置している。
sen.e: In the center stands the statue of Sanko Joeki, on the right are statues of Kita no Mandokoro's elder brother Iesada KINOSHITA and his wife Unsho-in, and on the left is a statue of Naomasa HORI who put great effort into the temple's construction.

In the center stands the statue of Sanko Joeki, on the right are statues of Kita no Mandokoro's elder brother Iesada KINOSHITA and his wife Unsho-in, and on the left is a statue of Naomasa HORI who put great effort into the temple's construction.

In the center stands the statue of Sanko Joeki, on the right are statues of Kita no Mandokoro's elder brother Iesada KINOSHITA and his wife Unshoin, and on the left is a statue of Naomasa HORI who put great effort into the temple's construction.
sen.cmt: 雲照院は女性の院号のため、Unsho-in→Unshoinに修正、temple’sのアポストロフィーを半角に変更

sen.j: この堂の天井は、秀吉の御座舟の天井と、北政所の御所車の天井を用いたものという。
sen.e: The ceiling is said to have been created from the ceilings of Hideyoshi's gaozafune, a boat for a person of elevated status, and Kita no Mandokoro's ox-drawn coach.
The ceiling is said to have been created from the ceilings of Hideyoshi's gaozafune, a boat for a person of elevated status, and Kita no Mandokoro's ox-drawn coach.
The ceiling is said to have been created from the ceilings of Hideyoshi's gaozafune, a boat for a person of elevated status, and Kita no Mandokoro's ox-drawn coach.

sen.j: 臥龍廊（がりょうろう）－開山堂と霊屋（おたまや）を結ぶ屋根付きの階段、龍の背に似ているところからこの名が付けられた。
sen.e: Garyoro (Reclining Dragon Corridor): This roofed staircase linking the Kaizan-do hall and mausoleum was given its name due to its resemblance to a dragon's back.
Garyoro (Reclining Dragon Corridor): This roofed staircase linking the Kaizan-do hall and mausoleum was given its name due to its resemblance to a dragon's back.
Garyoro (Reclining Dragon Corridor): This roofed staircase linking the Kaizan-do hall and mausoleum was given its name due to its resemblance to a dragon's back.

sen.j: 霊屋（重要文化財）－開山堂の西方、一段高くなった敷地に建つ、宝形造檜皮葺きの堂。
sen.e: Mausoleum (Important Cultural Property): This square hall, topped by hogyo-zukuri hiwadabuki, a pyramidal roof covered with Japanese cypress bark shingles, stands on a slightly elevated plot to the west of the Kaizan-do hall.

Mausoleum (Important Cultural Property): This square hall, topped by hogyo-zukuri hiwadabuki, a pyramidal roof covered with Japanese cypress bark shingles, stands on a slightly elevated plot to the west of the Kaizan-do hall.

Mausoleum (Important Cultural Property): This square hall, topped by hogyo-zukuri hiwadabuki, a pyramidal roof covered with Japanese cypress bark shingles, stands on a slightly elevated plot to the west of the Kaisan-do hall.

sen.j: 慶長10年（1605年）の建築。
sen.e: Constructed in 1605.
Constructed in 1605.
Constructed in 1605.

sen.j: 内部は中央の厨子（平素、扉を閉じている）に大随求菩薩（だいずいぐぼさつ）像を安置し、向かって右の厨子には豊臣秀吉の坐像、左の厨子には正室・北政所の片膝立の木像がそれぞれ安置されている。
sen.e: Inside, the central miniature shrine (doors ordinarily kept closed) houses a statue of the bodhisattva Maha Pratisara, the miniature shrine on the right houses a seated statue of Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, and the miniature shrine on the left houses a statue of his wife, Kita no Mandokoro, kneeling on one knee.

Inside, the central miniature shrine (doors ordinarily kept closed) houses a statue of the bodhisattva Maha Pratisara, the miniature shrine on the right houses a seated statue of Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, and the miniature shrine on the left houses a statue of his wife, Kita no Mandokoro, kneeling on one knee.

Inside, the central miniature shrine (doors ordinarily kept closed) houses a statue of the bodhisattva Maha Pratisara, the miniature shrine on the right houses a seated statue of Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, and the miniature shrine on the left houses a statue of his wife, Kita no Mandokoro, kneeling on one knee.

sen.j: 厨子の扉には秋草、松竹など、須弥壇には楽器などの蒔絵が施されている。
sen.e: The miniature shrine doors are adorned with makie imagery such as autumn flowers, pine trees and bamboo, and the shumidan (an altar made of fine timber, generally with panelling, hame) feature makie images which include musical instruments.

The miniature shrine doors are adorned with makie imagery such as autumn flowers, pine trees and bamboo, and the shumidan (an altar made of fine timber, generally with panelling, hame) feature makie images which include musical instruments.

The miniature shrine doors are adorned with makie imagery such as autumn flowers, pine trees and bamboo, and the shumidan (an altar made of fine timber, generally with panelling, hame) feature makie images which include musical instruments.

sen.j: 厨子の目立たぬところに蒔絵の作者の名が線描きされておりその点でも貴重。
sen.e: The miniatures shrines are also valuable as they feature the name of the artist responsible for creating the makie in inconspicuous locations.
The miniatures shrines are also valuable as they feature the name of the artist responsible for creating the makie in inconspicuous locations.
The miniatures shrines are also valuable as they feature the name of the artist responsible for creating the makie in inconspicuous locations.

sen.j: 寺に所蔵される、北政所所用と伝える調度品類にも同じ様式の蒔絵が施され、これらを高台寺蒔絵と称している。
sen.e: The furnishings in the temple's possession that are said to have been owned by Kita no Mandokoro are decorated with the same makie style known as 'Kodo-ji Temple Makie'.
The furnishings in the temple's possession that are said to have been owned by Kita no Mandokoro are decorated with the same makie style known as 'Kodo-ji Temple Makie'.
The furnishings in the temple's possession that are said to have been owned by Kita no Mandokoro are decorated with the same makie style known as 'Kodai-ji Makie.'
sen.cmt: Kodo-ji Temple Makie→Kodai-ji Makieに修正、ピリオドの位置を移動

sen.j: 高台寺蒔絵の特色は、金の平蒔絵（文様部分の漆を盛り上げずに、平滑に仕上げたもの）を主体に秋草などの絵画的な文様を描くことである。
sen.e: The main characteristic of Kodai-ji Makie are designs such as autumn flowers applied to golden flat makie (sprinkled powder applied directly on the smooth lacquered surface in very low relief so only the thickness of the final protective lacquer coating is raised above the surface).

The main characteristic of Kodai-ji Makie are designs such as autumn flowers applied to golden flat makie (sprinkled powder applied directly on the smooth lacquered surface in very low relief so only the thickness of the final protective lacquer coating is raised above the surface).

The main characteristic of Kodai-ji Makie are designs such as autumn flowers applied to golden flat makie (sprinkled powder applied directly on the smooth lacquered surface in very low relief so only the thickness of the final protective lacquer coating is raised above the surface).

sen.j: なお、北政所は自身の像の下に葬られている。
sen.e: Kita no Mandokoro is interred below her own statue.
Kita no Mandokoro is interred below her own statue.
Kita no Mandokoro is interred below her own statue.

sen.j: 茶室
sen.e: Teahouses
Teahouses
Teahouses

sen.j: 傘亭（安閑窟）（重要文化財）－境内東奥の小高い場所に位置する。
sen.e: Kasa-tei (Ankan-kutsu) (Important Cultural Property): Situated on a slightly elevated position in the east of the temple precinct.
Kasa-tei (Ankan-kutsu) (Important Cultural Property): Situated on a slightly elevated position in the east of the temple precinct.
Kasa-tei (Ankan-kutsu) (Important Cultural Property): Situated on a slightly elevated position in the east of the temple precinct.

sen.j: 伏見城から移築したものとされ、千利休の作、秀吉好みの茶室と伝える（ただし伏見城建設は利休の自刃後）。
sen.e: It is thought to have been relocated to the temple from Fushimi Castle and is said to have been created by SEN no Rikyu and particularly favored by Hideyoshi (although Fushimi Castle was constructed after SEN no Rikyu committed suicide).

It is thought to have been relocated to the temple from Fushimi Castle and is said to have been created by SEN no Rikyu and particularly favored by Hideyoshi (although Fushimi Castle was constructed after SEN no Rikyu committed suicide).

It is thought to have been relocated to the temple from Fushimi-jo Castle and is said to have been created by SEN no Rikyu and particularly favored by Hideyoshi (although Fushimi-jo Castle was constructed after SEN no Rikyu committed suicide).

sen.j: 宝形造茅葺きの素朴な建物で、内部の天井が竹で組まれ、その形が唐傘に似ている所から傘亭の名がある。
sen.e: The simple square building with a pyramidal thatched roof features on the inside a bamboo ceiling that looks like the underside of Chinese umbrella - from which it gets its name 'Kasa-tei' (lit. Umbrealla Pavillion).

The simple square building with a pyramidal thatched roof features on the inside a bamboo ceiling that looks like the underside of Chinese umbrella - from which it gets its name 'Kasa-tei' (lit. Umbrealla Pavillion).

The simple square building with a pyramidal thatched roof features on the inside a bamboo ceiling that looks like the underside of Chinese umbrella - from which it gets its name 'Kasa-tei' (lit. Umbrealla Pavillion).

sen.j: 時雨亭（重要文化財）－傘亭の南隣にあり、傘亭との間は屋根付きの土間廊下でつながれている。
sen.e: Shigure-tei (Important Cultural Property): Stands to the south of Kasa-tei, to which it is linked by a roofed walkway with a tiled floor.
Shigure-tei (Important Cultural Property): Stands to the south of Kasa-tei, to which it is linked by a roofed walkway with a tiled floor.
Shigure-tei (Important Cultural Property): Stands to the south of Kasa-tei, to which it is linked by a roofed walkway with a tiled floor.

sen.j: 珍しい2階建ての茶室で、2階南側の上段の間は柱間に壁や建具を設けない吹き放しとする。
sen.e: It is rare among teahouses as it has two storey, and an open-plan elevated-floor room in the south of the upper floor with no walls or fittings in the bays between pillars.
It is rare among teahouses as it has two stories, and an open-plan elevated-floor room in the south of the upper floor with no walls or fittings in the bays between pillars.
It is rare among teahouses as it has two stories, and an open-plan elevated-floor room in the south of the upper floor with no walls or fittings in the bays between pillars.

sen.j: 傘亭同様伏見城からの移築とされ、千利休の作、秀吉好みと伝える。
sen.e: As with Kasa-tei, it is thought to have been relocated to the temple from Fushimi Castle and is said to have been created by SEN no Rikyu and particularly favored by Hideyoshi.
As with Kasa-tei, it is thought to have been relocated to the temple from Fushimi Castle and is said to have been created by SEN no Rikyu and particularly favored by Hideyoshi.
As with Kasa-tei, it is thought to have been relocated to the temple from Fushimi-jo Castle and is said to have been created by SEN no Rikyu and particularly favored by Hideyoshi.

sen.j: 伏見城「御学問所」に擬する説もある。
sen.e: Some theories even claim that it may have been the Emperor's study room at Fushimi-jo Castle.
Some theories even claim that it may have been the Emperor's study room at Fushimi-jo Castle.
Some theories even claim that it may have been the Emperor's study room at Fushimi-jo Castle.

sen.j: 遺芳庵－方丈・書院の背後にある田舎屋風の茶室で、近世初期の茶人・灰屋紹益が夫人の吉野太夫をしのんで建てたものという。
sen.e: Iho-an: This rustic style teahouse, located behind the hojo and study, was constructed in the early modern period by a master of the tea ceremony Shoeki HAIYA in memory of his wife Yoshino Dayu.
Iho-an: This rustic style teahouse, located behind the hojo and study, was constructed in the early modern period by a master of the tea ceremony Shoeki HAIYA in memory of his wife Yoshino Dayu.
Iho-an: This rustic style teahouse, located behind the hojo and study, was constructed in the early modern period by a master of the tea ceremony Shoeki HAIYA in memory of his wife Yoshino Dayu.

sen.j: 一畳台目の小規模な茶席で、炉は逆勝手向切りとする。
sen.e: The tea ceremony set is small at around the size of a 3/4-length tatami mat, and the hearth (firebox) is cut into the left inner edge of the host's mat.
The tea ceremony set is small at around the size of a 3/4-length tatami mat, and the hearth (firebox) is cut into the left inner edge of the host's mat.

sen.j: 吉野窓と称する、壁一杯に開けられた丸窓が特色である。
sen.e: Also features a unique large round window known as a 'yoshinomado' that takes up almost an entire wall.
Also features a unique large round window known as a 'yoshinomado' that takes up almost an entire wall.
Also features a unique large round window known as a 'yoshinomado' that takes up almost an entire wall.

sen.e: a Front Gate (Important Cultural Property)
a Front Gate (Important Cultural Property)

sen.j: 庭園（史跡・名勝）－小堀遠州作とされ、しだれ桜とハギの名所。
sen.e: Garden (Special Historic Site/Special Site of Scenic Beauty): Thought to have been created by Enshu KOBORI, and famous for its weeping cherry blossom trees and Japanese clover.
Garden (Special Historic Site/Special Site of Scenic Beauty): Thought to have been created by Enshu KOBORI, and famous for its weeping cherry blossom trees and Japanese clover.
Garden (Special Historic Site/Special Site of Scenic Beauty): Thought to have been created by Enshu KOBORI, and famous for its weeping cherry blossom trees and Japanese clover.

sen.j: 石組みの見事さは桃山時代を代表する庭園として知られる。
sen.e: The beauty of the arranged stones makes this garden highly representative of the Momoyama period.
The beauty of the arranged stones makes this garden highly representative of the Momoyama period.
The beauty of the arranged stones makes this garden highly representative of the Momoyama period.

sen.j: 圓徳院(えんとくいん)
sen.e: Entoku-in Temple
Entoku-in Temple
Entoku-in Temple

sen.j: 秀吉の没後に北政所が晩年を過ごした所であり、北政所の終焉の地となった。
sen.e: The place in which Kita no Mandokoro spent her last years after the death of Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI and where she passed away.
The place in which Kita no Mandokoro spent her last years after the death of Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI and where she passed away.

sen.j: 長谷川等伯筆 襖絵（重要文化財）

Sliding partition paintings by Tohaku HASEGAWA (Important Cultural Property)

sen.j: もと大徳寺三玄院の襖絵。
sen.e: Originally located at the Sangen-in of Daitoku-ji Temple.
Originally located at the Sangen-in of Daitoku-ji Temple.
Originally located at the Sangen-in of Daitoku-ji Temple.

sen.j: 廃仏毀釈に際して圓徳院の蔵するところとなる（他に楽家も所蔵）。
sen.e: Came into the possession of Entoku-in Temple during the expulsion of Buddhism in Japan at the beginning of the Meiji era.
Came into the possession of Entoku-in Temple during the expulsion of Buddhism in Japan at the beginning of the Meiji era.
Came into the possession of Entoku-in Temple during the expulsion of Buddhism in Japan at the beginning of the Meiji era.

sen.j: 桐紋雲母（きらら）刷りの唐紙襖に描かれた非常に珍しいもので、等伯が住職に襖絵製作を申し出ていたが許されなかったので、住職の留守中に一気に描きあげてしまったものだと伝えられる。
sen.e: These unique pieces feature the Paulownia Seal mica-printed onto Chinese paper screens and are said to have all been created in a single batch while the head priest was away after Tohaku proposed the idea of painted screens to him but was refused.

These unique pieces feature the Paulownia Seal mica-printed onto Chinese paper screens and are said to have all been created in a single batch while the head priest was away after Tohaku proposed the idea of painted screens to him but was refused.

sen.j: 北庭（名勝）

sen.cmt: 他の表記と同様、単語の頭文字を大文字に統一

sen.j: 伏見城の北政所化粧御殿の前庭を移築したもので、桃山時代の代表的な庭園である。
sen.e: This typical Momoyama period garden was the front garden of Kita no Mandokoro's Kesho Goten Palace that was also relocated from Fushimi-jo Castle.
This typical Momoyama period garden was the front garden of Kita no Mandokoro's Kesho Goten Palace that was also relocated from Fushimi-jo Castle.

sen.j: 月真院
sen.e: Gesshin-in Temple
Gesshin-in Temple
Gesshin-in Temple

sen.j: 元和2(1616)年に北政所の従弟・久林玄昌が亀井豊前守の外護により建立。
sen.e: Constructed in 1616 by Kita no Mandokoro's younger male cousin Gensho HISABAYASHI for the protection of Buzennokami KAMEI.
Constructed in 1616 by Kita no Mandokoro's younger male cousin Gensho HISABAYASHI for the protection of Buzennokami KAMEI.
Constructed in 1616 by Kita no Mandokoro's younger male cousin Gensho HISABAYASHI for the protection of Buzennokami KAMEI.

sen.j: 幕末には、禁裏御陵衛士を拝命した伊東甲子太郎(いとうかしたろ)以下15名が屯所を構えた。
sen.e: At the end of the Edo period, Kashitaro ITO established the Kinri Goryo Eji (a splinter group of the Shinsengumi), and he and 15 others set up a headquarters at the temple.
At the end of the Edo period, Kashitaro ITO established the Kinri Goryo Eji (a splinter group of the Shinsengumi), and he and 15 others set up a headquarters at the temple.
At the end of the Edo period, Kashitaro ITO established the Kinri Goryo Eji (a splinter group of the Shinsengumi), and he and 15 others set up a headquarters at the temple.

sen.j: 掌（しょう）美術館 －境内から公道を挟んで西側、飲食店の2階に位置する小美術館。
sen.e: Sho Museum: A small museum located on the second floor of a restaurant across the road that boarders the west of the temple precinct.
Sho Museum: A small museum located on the second floor of a restaurant across the road that boarders the west of the temple precinct.
Sho Museum: A small museum located on the second floor of a restaurant across the road that boarders the west of the temple precincts.

sen.j: 豊臣秀吉、北政所の肖像画のほか、調度品、絵画、文書など高台寺所蔵の美術品を多数保存、展示する。
sen.e: The museum preserves and displays Kodaiji Temple's numerous works of art including furnishings, paintings and books in addition to portraits of Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI and Kita no Mandokoro.
The museum preserves and displays Kodaiji Temple's numerous works of art including furnishings, paintings and books in addition to portraits of Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI and Kita no Mandokoro.
The museum preserves and displays Kodai-ji Temple's numerous works of art including furnishings, paintings and books in addition to portraits of Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI and Kita no Mandokoro.

sen.j: 台所坂 －ねねの道から高台寺の境内へと続く道で、北政所は秀吉の菩提を弔うためにこの道を往き来したといわれる。
sen.e: Daidokoro-zaka: These stone steps lead from Nene no michi road to the Daidokoro-ji Temple precinct, and it is said that Kita no Mandokoro would walk up and down this path to pray for the soul of her husband Hideyoshi.

Daidokoro-zaka: These stone steps lead from Nene no michi road to the Daidokoro-ji Temple precinct, and it is said that Kita no Mandokoro would walk up and down this path to pray for the soul of her husband Hideyoshi.

Daidokoro-zaka slope: These stone steps lead from Nene no Michi path to the Kodai-ji Temple precincts, and it is said that Kita no Mandokoro would walk up and down this path to pray for the soul of her husband Hideyoshi.
sen.cmt: Daidokoro-zaka slope、Nene no Michi pathとし, Daidokoro-ji Temple precinct→Kodai-ji Temple precinctsに修正

sen.j: ねねの道 －知恵の道、神幸道と合わせて東山参道（三つの道）と言い、円山公園 (京都府)付近で接続して、それぞれ知恩院、八坂神社へと続く。
sen.e: Nene no michi (Path of Nene): This path, that starts in the area of Maruyama Park (Kyoto Prefecture) and continues to Chion-in Temple and Yasaka-jinja Shrine, is one of the 'Higashiyama Sando' (three approaches) along with Chie no michi and Shinko michi.

Nene no michi (Path of Nene): This path, that starts in the area of Maruyama Park (Kyoto Prefecture) and continues to Chion-in Temple and Yasaka-jinja Shrine, is one of the 'Higashiyama Sando' (three approaches) along with Chie no michi and Shinko michi.

Nene no michi (Path of Nene): This path, that starts in the area of Maruyama Park (Kyoto Prefecture) and continues to Chion-in Temple and Yasaka-jinja Shrine, is one of the 'Higashiyama Sando' (three approaches) along with Chie no michi path and Shinko michi path.
sen.cmt: Chie no michi path, Shinko michi pathとしました。
